title: How to Clean a Cake Pan

methods.name: Soaking the Pan with Soap and Hot Water

steps.headline: Add 3-5 drops of liquid dish soap to the dirty pan.
steps.description: Any type of liquid soap will do the trick, but ultra-strength grease-dissolving detergents will work best, as they contain higher concentrations of abrasive surfactants. The combination of heat and gentle abrasion will go to work on the worst of the caked-on crud in the pan before you ever lift a finger. When cleaning particularly large pans, you can use as many as 8-10 drops, or drizzle a thin line of soap along the walls and bottom surface.

steps.headline: Fill the pan with hot water.
steps.description: Turn on the tap and wait for the water to warm up. Once it’s steaming hot, run the water into the pre-soaped cake pan. Together, the soap and water will form a sudsy solution perfect for softening up messes that are too heavy for a normal hand washing. Make sure you fill the pan all the way to the top. That way, the solution will touch each part of the pan covered with cake remnants or brown, crusty buildup from past baking projects. Be careful handling your pan after filling it with hot water. The metal may be quite warm.

steps.headline: Let the pan soak for about half an hour.
steps.description: Now, just move the pan to the neighboring section of the sink and go about your regularly-scheduled business. In the meantime, the soap solution time will begin loosening up all the hardened gunk clinging to the surface. Keep an eye on the clock so you’ll know how long the pan has been soaking.Tip: If you’re up against especially thick or long-standing residue, you can also leave the pan to soak for several hours, or even overnight.

steps.headline: Scrub the pan thoroughly while rinsing it with hot water.
steps.description: Once the pan has had a chance to soak, come back and drain the dirty soap solution, then run it under a stream of hot water. As you do, go over any remaining residue or discoloration with a soft-bristled dish brush or the rough side of a kitchen sponge. Flexible, nylon-bristled bottle brushes can be useful for getting down into the nooks, crannies, and contours of irregularly-shaped bundt, cupcake, and novelty pans. Steel wool can also come in handy for scraping off burnt and hardened residue that puts up a fight. Only use steel wool on pans made from glass or stainless steel, however, as it can easily ruin an aluminum pan.

steps.headline: Give the pan a final rinse.
steps.description: Set your brush or sponge aside and rotate the pan 360 degrees under the stream of water to wash out the last of the soap solution and displaced residue. Continue rinsing until the water runs clear, then shake off the excess moisture and pat the pan dry inside and out with a clean, absorbent towel. Be sure to rinse away all traces of the soap solution. If you allow it to dry on the pan, it may leave behind a waxy film, which could affect the taste of future confections. If you'd prefer to let your pan air-dry, place it upside down on a drying rack or mat to prevent water from collecting at the bottom. A good soak should be enough to deal with most light messes. If the pan is still visibly dirty afterwards, you may need to try a more intensive cleaning method.

methods.name: Busting Stubborn Residue with Vinegar and Baking Soda

steps.headline: Pour a small amount of baking soda into the pan.
steps.description: Crack open a box of baking soda and shake out a thin layer over the entire bottom surface of the pan. Try to distribute the powder as evenly as you can. No need to overdo it. A little baking soda goes a long way. Sodium bicarbonate, the chemical name for baking soda, is abrasive yet still gentle enough to use on most metals, which is why it will serve as the main ingredient in your cleaning paste.Warning: Think twice before trying this method on an aluminum cake pan. Aluminum is a soft metal, and slathering it with baking soda could lead to mild scratching, pitting, or discoloration, if you’re not careful.

steps.headline: Add 2-3 generous pinches of sea salt.
steps.description: Sprinkle the salt on top of the baking soda, again aiming for full coverage over the bottom of the pan. Baking soda and sea salt make a formidable tag-team of abrasive agents effective for effortless hands-free cleaning. You can also use coarse-ground cooking salt or kosher salt if you don’t have any sea salt on hand. The larger the grains, the better.

steps.headline: Spritz the baking soda and salt with distilled white vinegar to create a paste.
steps.description: Pour the vinegar into a small spray bottle and mist your dry ingredients liberally. Keep spraying until the three components form a mixture that’s roughly the same consistency as shaving cream. Introducing vinegar to the baking soda will kickstart a chemical reaction and create a fizzy, foamy cleaner that essentially does all the hard work for you. Hydrogen peroxide can also make an acceptable substitute for vinegar—just don’t combine the two. Doing so can produce peracetic acid, which is a mildly toxic substance that could cause eye, skin, or airway irritation.

steps.headline: Let the paste sit on the pan for up to 2 hours.
steps.description: The beauty of this method is that it works all by itself. All you have to do is apply the paste and figure out what to do with the time that you won’t be using to scrub your cookware by hand. If you’re in a hurry to use your favorite cake pan, 30-60 minutes should be enough time to get the job done. The longer the paste set up on the pan, the better it will work.

steps.headline: Rinse the pan thoroughly with warm water.
steps.description: Once the allotted time is up, hold the pan under a warm faucet to clear away the dingy paste. Turn and tilt the pan slowly under the stream to make sure that the water hits each part. When you’re done, you’ll find that the paste has eaten away most if not all of the grimy residue. You made need to wipe the pan lightly with a soft sponge or cloth to dislodge any bits that are still hanging on following your initial rinse. Towel-dry your pan immediately after cleaning it to prevent rust.

methods.name: Cutting Through Baked-on Messes with Oxalic Acid

steps.headline: Wet the surface of the pan with warm water.
steps.description: Run the water over the inside of the pan, then let it drain out. It’s not necessary to actually fill the pan—you just need for there to be enough moisture on it to turn the powdered cleaner into a thick paste. Giving your pan a preliminary rinse will also help remove any fresh cake residue stuck to the sides or bottom.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the pan with a light coating of oxalic acid powder.
steps.description: Try to dust the entire inner surface of the pan evenly. It's especially important that the powder contacts each part of the pan where residue or discoloration is the heaviest. Oxalic acid is the primary ingredient in many different commercial cleaning powders. It’s generally considered safe for use on all sorts of cookware, including aluminum. Some popular cleaning powders that contain oxalic acid are also sold in liquid form, which could help simplify frequent cleaning tasks.

steps.headline: Let the paste sit in the pan for about 5 minutes.
steps.description: As it sits, the abrasive particles in the cleaning powder will begin to break down any and all foreign substances that have set up on the metal surface. This is crucial for deep-cleaning old and extensively-used cookware, so be patient and give the product plenty of time to act before you take over. Watch the clock or set a timer on your phone to keep track of how long the powder has been working. Abrasives cause minor deterioration, so you don’t want to leave it in the pan for too long.

steps.headline: Scrub the pan clean with the rough side of a kitchen sponge.
steps.description: Glide the sponge back and forth along the surface of the pain using quick, tight circular motions, applying steady pressure the entire time. The cleaning powder, combined with a little elbow grease or your own, should be able to gradually wear down even the most persistent buildup. Sponges are generally better suited for serious cleaning and renewal than brushes, since you can put more of your weight behind them. Press your finger into one corner of the sponge and use it to get reach down into the deep crevices of molded and contoured pans. Oxalic acid is a mild, naturally-occurring compound, so there’s little chance of it irritating your hands. Still, it may be a good idea to pull on a pair of dish gloves if you’ve got sensitive skin.Tip: For even more scour power, ball up a sheet of aluminum foil and use it to go over the pan instead.

steps.headline: Rinse the pan thoroughly with soap and water.
steps.description: Flush out the pan a few times to get rid of any lingering cleaner. Then, squeeze in a couple drops of liquid dish soap and fill it with warm water. Swish the solution around inside the pan to ensure that it’s nice and clean before draining it and drying it by hand. Another option is to rinse your pan with boiling water to loosen up any residue that’s still holding onto the surface. If a single scrubbing doesn’t cut it, feel free to repeat the process as many times as needed until your pan shines like new.
